message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UASs): Current State, Emerging Technologies, and Future Trends
Paper Abstract: Unmanned aircraft, commonly referred to as drones, represent a valuable alternative for various operational tasks due to their versatility, flexibility, cost-effectiveness, and reusability. These features make them particularly advantageous in environments that are hazardous or inaccessible to humans. Recent developments have highlighted a significant increase in the use of unmanned aircraft within metropolitan areas. This growth has necessitated the implementation of new regulations and guidelines to ensure the safe integration of UAS into urban environments. Consequently, the concept of UAM has emerged. UAM refers to an innovative air transportation paradigm designed for both passengers and cargo within urban settings, leveraging the capabilities of drones. This review manuscript explores the latest advancements for UAS, focusing on updated regulations, definitions, enabling technologies, and airspace classifications relevant to UAM operations. Additionally, it provides a comprehensive overview of unmanned aircraft systems, including their classifications, key features, and primary applications.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Drone carrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drone_carrier"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned aircraft system simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aircraft_system_simulation"},{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"General Atomics MQ-9 Reaper - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Atomics_MQ-9_Reaper"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"Manned-unmanned teaming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_combat_aircraft"},{"title":"UPS Flight Forward - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UPS_Flight_Forward"}]

Here's an overview of drone aircraft based on the search results:

## Definition and Basics

A drone, or unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)In common usage, "drone" is often applied to both military and civilian UAVs, while technical and regulatory documents may prefer terms such as UAV, UAS, RPAS, or uncrewed aircraft.

## Types and Classifications

Drones can vary significantly in design and purpose:

- **Military Applications**: Unmanned combat aerial vehicles (UCAVs), also known as combat drones, carry aircraft ordnance such as air-to-surface missiles, anti-tank guided missiles, and/or aerial bombs, allowing them to perform tactical attacks known as drone strikes.

- **Commercial Uses**: For recreational uses, an aerial photography drone is an aircraft that has first-person video, autonomous capabilities, or both. Beyond recreation, firefighters, police, miners, and weather researchers now use UAVs, which were first used in military sectors.

- **Size and Cost Range**: These unmanned systems range in cost from a few thousand dollars to tens of millions of dollars, with aircraft weighing from less than one pound to over 40,000 pounds.

## Modern Technologies

Autonomous drones employ advanced technologies that allow them to carry out their missions without human intervention, such as cloud computing, computer vision, artificial intelligence, machine learning, deep learning, and thermal sensors.

- **Size and Cost Range**: These unmanned systems range in cost from a few thousand dollars to tens of millions of dollars, with aircraft weighing from less than one pound to over 40,000 pounds.

## Modern Technologies

Autonomous drones employ advanced technologies that allow them to carry out their missions without human intervention, such as cloud computing, computer vision, artificial intelligence, machine learning, deep learning, and thermal sensors.

I've performed a web search for "Aircraft regulation" and found comprehensive information. Here's an overview of what was found:

## Overview of Aircraft Regulation

The Federal Aviation Regulations (FARs) are rules prescribed by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) governing all aviation activities in the United States.(no content)The FARs comprise Title 14 of the Code of Federal Regulations (14 CFR).

## Global Regulatory Bodies

Most countries have regulatory authorities devoted to producing and publishing regulations for aeronautical operations. In Canada, the publication is called Canadian Aviation Regulations, produced by Transport Canada. For European States, regulations are produced by the European Aviation Safety Agency. In the United States, the publication is called Federal Aviation Regulations, produced by the Federal Aviation Administration.

## Key Regulatory Functions

Aircraft regulation covers several important areas:

- **Aircraft Certification**: A type certificate (TC) is issued to signify the airworthiness of the approved design or "type" of an aircraft to be manufactured. Once issued, the design cannot be changed unless at least part of the process for certification is repeated to cover the changes.

- **Flight Operations**: Flight rules are regulations and procedures adopted for flying aircraft in various conditions.

- **International Standards**: The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) provides general rules and mediates international concerns regarding aviation law. The ICAO is a specialized agency of the United Nations.

The search results provide detailed information about regulatory frameworks, certification processes, and the various organizations responsible for aircraft safety and operations worldwide.

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Mobile-Low, Slow, Small Unmanned Aircraft Integrated Defeat System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile-Low,_Slow,_Small_Unmanned_Aircraft_Integrated_Defeat_System"},{"title":"Unmanned aircraft system simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aircraft_system_simulation"},{"title":"Unmanned aircraft system traffic management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aircraft_system_traffic_management"},{"title":"Unmanned aircraft in Singapore - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aircraft_in_Singapore"},{"title":"On-Demand Small Unmanned Aircraft System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/On-Demand_Small_Unmanned_Aircraft_System"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"Dassault nEUROn - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dassault_nEUROn"},{"title":"BAE Systems Mantis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BAE_Systems_Mantis"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Unmanned Aircraft Systems:

## Definition

An unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Components

An unmanned aircraft system includes a ground-based controller and a system of communications with the aircraft, along with elements such as ground control stations, data links and other support equipment.

## Types of Control

The flight of UAVs may operate under remote control by a human operator, as remotely piloted aircraft (RPA), or with various degrees of autonomy, such as autopilot assistance, up to fully autonomous aircraft that have no provision for human intervention.

## Terminology

The term UAS was adopted by the United States Department of Defense (DoD) and the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) in 2005 according to their Unmanned Aircraft System Roadmap 2005–2030.

## Applications

UAVs are usually deployed for military and special operation applications, but are also used in a small but growing number of civil applications, such as policing and firefighting, and nonmilitary security work such as surveillance of pipelines.

The flight of UAVs may operate under remote control by a human operator, as remotely piloted aircraft (RPA), or with various degrees of autonomy, such as autopilot assistance, up to fully autonomous aircraft that have no provision for human intervention.

## Terminology

The term UAS was adopted by the United States Department of Defense (DoD) and the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) in 2005 according to their Unmanned Aircraft System Roadmap 2005–2030.

## Applications

UAVs are usually deployed for military and special operation applications, but are also used in a small but growing number of civil applications, such as policing and firefighting, and nonmilitary security work such as surveillance of pipelines.

Here are the search results for **Urban Air Mobility**:

## Definition and Overview

Urban air mobility (UAM) refers to the use of small, highly automated aircraft for the transportation of passengers or cargo at low altitudes within urban and suburban areas.(no content)This development has emerged as a response to increasing traffic congestion.

## Key Technologies

The term generally refers to existing and emerging technologies such as traditional helicopters, vertical-takeoff-and-landing aircraft (VTOL), electrically propelled vertical-takeoff-and-landing aircraft (eVTOL), and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs).(no content)These aircraft are characterized by the use of multiple electric-powered rotors or fans for lift and propulsion, along with fly-by-wire systems to control them.

## Recent Development

Advances in materials, computerized flight controls, batteries, and electric motors improved innovation and designs beginning in the late 2010s. The UAM market has grown significantly, with multiple companies developing eVTOL aircraft and infrastructure worldwide.

## Current Projects and Operations

As part of World Expo 2025 in Osaka Japan plans to orchestrate nearly 30,000 eVTOL air taxi flights.(no content)Airbus Helicopters is developing a flying taxi, CityAirbus NextGen, targeted to begin service between 2026 and 2030.(no content)In 2025, Joby and Delta Air Lines hope to launch eVTOL flights in New York and Los Angeles.

Web search results for query: "Airspace"

Links: [{"title":"Airspace - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airspace"},{"title":"Airspace types (United States) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airspace_class_(United_States)"},{"title":"Prohibited airspace - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prohibited_airspace"},{"title":"Canadian airspace - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_airspace"},{"title":"Uncontrolled airspace - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncontrolled_airspace"},{"title":"National Airspace System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Airspace_System"},{"title":"Airspace Use Plan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airspace_Use_Plan"},{"title":"Controlled airspace - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controlled_airspace"},{"title":"2025 Pakistani airspace closure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Pakistani_airspace_closure"},{"title":"Military airspace - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_airspace"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about airspace:

## Definition

Airspace is the portion of the atmosphere controlled by a country above its territory and territorial waters that fall under the country's sovereignty and regulatory control.

## International Management

Internationally, allocation and management of airspace is coordinated by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), which was established through the Chicago Convention in 1947 to unify air traffic.(no content)ICAO organizes airspace into Flight Information Regions (FIRs) and provides classification guidelines.

## Sovereign Airspace Boundaries

By law, a country has the right to airspace above its land and waters up to 12 miles from their coast (if present). Beyond 12 miles, airspace is considered international.(no content)Most countries use the Kármán Line, 100km (62mi), as the legal distinction between airspace and outer space.

## Airspace Classes

Airspace is divided into multiple classes which dictate what services are provided in different areas. The classes are defined by ICAO, but countries are free to allocate different sections of airspace to different classes as they wish. There are 7 classes, A-G, with progressively less strict restrictions.

## Types of Airspace

Controlled airspace is airspace of defined dimensions within which air traffic control (ATC) services are provided. Conversely, uncontrolled airspace is airspace in which an air traffic control (ATC) service is not deemed necessary or cannot be provided for practical reasons.(no content)Airspace can be used for both civilian flight and for defense or military operations, and countries are responsible for protecting their own airspace using measures such as air policing.
